instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Okay, i'm stuck on this one. There is no liquid spill, board is clean.

Board will start up totally fine sometimes, and then cut out into a 1/4 fan spin issue.

PPBUS-G3H is bouncing on the scope, as well as PPDCIN-G3H,

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is also cycling. 

I have replaced all current sense resisters, even though they where okay. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, and the SMC. 

Its like the board has a short somewhere, but I cant find it.

Any clues ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
Please mark as solved, this was fixed by replacing <CAPACITOR>C8371</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C8340</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C8390</CAPACITOR>.

I've spent too much time on this board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Were they corroded looking, smell bad, physically damaged or what?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> intermittent start 1/4 fan spin
threads.message:
The tants looked ok, I only replaced as I was out of ideas, so started lightly heating some parts of the board to see if the short would go away. it would go away when i placed heat at <CAPACITOR>C8340</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C8390</CAPACITOR>. Replaced those.
Looking directly on the other side of the board, GND side of <CAPACITOR>C8371</CAPACITOR> was oxidized.
